channel.title: cata-list
channel.description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

item.title: SpaceX Brings Astronauts Home Safely in a Historic First
item.description: That's a wrap on SpaceX's crewed demo mission, which clears the way for the company to regularly launch astronauts for NASA.

item.title: The Piety of the Impious
item.description: Writing with not a little insight, commentators have observed a deeply intriguing dimension to the protests currently convulsing the United States: Percolating beneath the callow progressivism lies a kind of spiritual fervour, which animates a great swathe of the demonstrators. It's not simply the c…

item.title: Data Isn't Just Being Collected From Your Phone. It's Being Used to Score You.
item.description: It's called surveillance scoring. And everybody's doing it.

item.title: What Are Stingrays and Dirtboxes?
item.description: A guide to stingray surveillance technology, which may have been deployed at recent protests.

item.title: Americans Are Self-Censoring at Record Rates
item.description: The percentage of Americans afraid to share their political views has tripled.

item.title: NASA Just Launched Its New Perseverance Rover to Mars
item.description: The new rover is its biggest, most autonomous yet and may lead us to the first signs of ancient life on the Red Planet.

item.title: The Panopticon Is Already Here
item.description: Xi Jinping is using artificial intelligence to enhance his government's totalitarian control—and he's exporting this technology to regimes around the globe.

item.title: The New Fight to Hold Purdue Pharma and the Sacklers Accountable for the Opioid Crisis
item.description: Victim advocates fear that bankruptcy will shield the drugmaker from justice, but they're not giving up.

item.title: How to Spot — and Avoid — Dark Patterns on the Web
item.description: You've seen them before: the UX ploys designed to trick you into spending money, or make it nearly impossible to unsubscribe. Here's what to look out for.

item.title: Our Oppressive Moment
item.description: As one of the signatories to the much-discussed 'Open Letter' in Harper's magazine, I've been bemused by the objection that we are merely whiners—people with impregnable career success, flustered that social media is forcing us to experience unprecedented criticism, particularly in the wake of the F…

item.title: Largest Nuclear Fusion Project Begins Assembly
item.description: The world's biggest nuclear fusion project has entered its five-year assembly phase.

item.title: Understanding Totalitarianism
item.description: In recent years, amid concern about a possible resurgence of totalitarianism, a number of books and articles have appeared that are intended to warn about the rhetoric and behavior of the populist Right. At the same time, a countercurrent of public intellectuals and journalists have leveled similar …

item.title: Internal Source Code From 50 High-Profile Companies Including Microsoft, Disney, and Nintendo Has Been Leaked and Posted Online for People to Access
item.description: 'Losing control of the source code on the internet is like handing the blueprints of a bank to robbers,' a security expert told tech blog Tom's Guide.

item.title: To Unite the Country, We Need Honesty and Courage
item.description: All of us must speak the truth — including painful truths that unsettle not only our foes but also our friends and ourselves.

item.title: It's Not Just Siberia as Record Heat Spreads Across the Arctic
item.description: Siberia has been hot and on fire. Perhaps you've heard? The relentless heat that's buffeted the region has decided to expand to other parts of the Arctic, from Norway to Canada, with high-temperature records breaking over the weekend.

item.title: The Myth of Pervasive Misogyny
item.description: Women who seek to be equal with men lack ambition. ~Timothy Leary Many feminists and progressives argue that the West is plagued by pervasive misogyny. In fact, this claim is made with such frequency, and is so rarely challenged, that it has become part of the Left's catechism of victimhood, repeate…

item.title: We're Publishing Thousands of Police Discipline Records That New York Kept Secret for Decades
item.description: ProPublica obtained these police records from New York City's Civilian Complaint Review Board. NYPD unions are suing to halt the city from making the data public.

item.title: Russia's GRU Hackers Hit US Government and Energy Targets
item.description: A previously unreported Fancy Bear campaign persisted for well over a year.

item.title: Of Heroic Deeds and Hysterical Masses
item.description: Perpetual progress is no more possible than perpetual motion, an axiom unwittingly vindicated by the benighted throngs that currently run amok across America, menacing the living and long dead wherever they rage. Whereas in the final decade of the 19th century, 'enlightenment had progressed to the p…

item.title: Routine Beatings of Inmates in Alabama Prisons Go Ignored, U.S. Says
item.description: A report released by the Justice Department found that corrections officers frequently used excessive force and violated prisoners' constitutional rights.

item.title: Russia Accused of Firing Satellite Weapon in Space
item.description: The UK says the Russian satellite launched 'a projectile with the characteristics of a weapon'.

item.title: A Security Breach Exposed More Than One Million DNA Profiles on a Major Genealogy Database
item.description: First GEDmatch, the DNA database that helped identify the Golden State Killer, was hacked. Then email addresses from its users were used in a phishing attack on another leading genealogy site.

item.title: Poll: 62% of Americans Say They Have Political Views They're Afraid to Share
item.description: 50% of strong liberals support firing Trump donors, 36% of strong conservatives support firing Biden donors; 32% are worried about missing out on job opportunities because of their political opinions

item.title: Ongoing Meow Attack Has Nuked >1,000 Databases Without Telling Anyone Why
item.description: Ongoing attack hitting unsecured data leaves the word 'meow' as its calling card.

item.title: How to Sell Protest Footage to FOX and CNN
item.description: I am a videographer who has figured out the technique to sell my footage to both of these news outlets. You can to if you follow my very important guidelines...

item.title: Ancient Ice Loss in Antarctica's Most Stable Region Paints a Bleak Picture of What Could Come
item.description: A new paper suggests that the East Antarctic ice sheet may not be as stable as we thought. Looking at ancient melting, the study finds evidence that this piece of the Antarctic experienced melting 400,000 years ago when the world was 1.8 to 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit (1 to 2 degrees Celsius) warmer. Eno…

item.title: Obesity, Infertility, and Low IQ Are Just Some of the Ways Household Chemicals Wreck Our Health
item.description: A new analysis published in the Lancet Diabetes and Endocrinology on Tuesday found that a growing number of endocrine-disrupting household chemicals have been linked to widespread health problems, including infertility, diabetes, and impaired brain development. The researchers examined hundreds of s…

item.title: US Charges Two Chinese Spies in Global Hacking Campaign Targeting COVID-19 Research
item.description: The hackers are accused of a hacking spree lasting more than a decade.

item.title: It's Becoming Clear Why the US' Response to COVID-19 Is Terrible
item.description: Multiple reports make it obvious that facts aren't driving pandemic management.

item.title: By your powers combined: We are Social Justice Warriors
item.description: Dewdawg presents, By your powers combined: We are SOCIAL JUSTICE Warriors EPISODE intro 'Get TRIGGERED' * original movie created for 'No safe Spaces' release...

item.title: The Terrible Consequences of Australia's Uber-Bushfires
item.description: Scientists calculate that the unprecedented wildfires burned 37,500 square miles. For already endangered species, the conflagration may have spelled doom.

item.title: Son of Federal Judge in Epstein Deutsche Bank Case Shot Dead
item.description: Judge Esther Salas was appointed to the case last Wednesday. On Sunday, her 20-year-old son, and her husband, were shot at home.

item.title: The Truth According to Social Justice — A Review of 'Cynical Theories'
item.description: A review of Cynical Theories: How Activist Scholarship Made Everything about Race, Gender, and Identity―and Why This Harms Everybody, by Helen Pluckrose and James Lindsay, Pitchstone Publishing (August 25th, 2020), 352 pages. In November 1964, the American historian Richard Hofstadter published an e…

item.title: The Left Is Now the Right
item.description: We laughed at the Republican busybody who couldn't joke, declared war on dirty paintings, and peered through your bedroom window. Now that person has switched sides, and nobody's laughing

item.title: When Wokes and Racists Actually Agree on Everything
item.description: No description provided.

item.title: Antifa SJWs Assault Man for Free Speech Sign (UK)
item.description: Antifa fascists assaulted this man for simply having a sign that said: 'the right to openly discuss ideas must be defended.' The leader of Black Lives Matter...

item.title: On Eve of Bankruptcy, U.S. Firms Shower Execs With Bonuses
item.description: Nearly a third of more than 40 large companies seeking U.S. bankruptcy protection during the coronavirus pandemic awarded bonuses to executives within a month of filing their cases, according to a Reuters analysis of securities filings and court records.

item.title: Narcissists, Psychopaths, and Manipulators Are More Likely to Engage in 'Virtuous Victim Signaling,' Says Study
item.description: Plus: Protesters sue over alleged mistreatment by arresting officers, a new ruling on robocalls, and more...

item.title: Uighur Exiles Push for Court Case Accusing China of Genocide
item.description: The complaint at the International Criminal Court is the first of its kind to challenge Beijing on its crackdown on Muslims, but China does not accept the court's jurisdiction.

item.title: Bloody Harvest — How Everyone Ignored the Crime of the Century
item.description: In June of this year the China Tribunal delivered its Final Judgement and Summary Report.1 An independent committee composed of lawyers, human rights experts, and a transplant surgeon, the Tribunal was established to investigate forced organ harvesting on the Chinese mainland. These rumours have hau…

item.title: U.S. Breaks Record With Over 77,000 New Coronavirus Cases in Single Day
item.description: The U.S. recorded 77,255 new cases of coronavirus on Thursday, setting a depressing new world record. The U.S. has the worst outbreak on the planet right now, but it's probably more accurate to say this new record was broken last week. Why? The largest private testing lab in the country is currently…

item.title: Georgia Massaged Virus Data to Reopen, Then Voided Mask Orders
item.description: Georgia Governor Brian Kemp's edict expressly voiding coronavirus mask orders by local governments capped a week of turmoil in a state once touted as proof that reopening in a pandemic could work.

item.title: The U.S. Had a Record Number of Overdose Deaths Last Year
item.description: The covid-19 pandemic isn't the only public health crisis the U.S. is currently dealing with, as new government data released this week illustrates. In 2019, there were nearly 71,000 deaths attributed to drug overdose, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the highest yearly n…

item.title: Doordash and Thousands of Other Companies Passively Send Your Data to Facebook
item.description: But you can do something about it

item.title: Back to School: Teachers Are Ready to Quit Rather Than Put Their Lives at Risk
item.description: 'Most parents have no idea how bad this is going to be.'

item.title: U.S., Britain and Canada Say Russian Cyberspies Are Trying to Steal Coronavirus Vaccine Research
item.description: Hackers launched 'despicable attacks against those doing vital work to combat the coronavirus pandemic,' a top British intelligence official said.

item.title: Dr. Anthony Fauci Pleads With Young People: 'You're Propagating the Pandemic'
item.description: White House coronavirus advisor Dr. Anthony Fauci urged young Americans to not take the coronavirus lightly, saying doing so could propagate the pandemic.

item.title: EU Court Again Rules That NSA Spying Makes U.S. Companies Inadequate for Privacy
item.description: The European Union's highest court today made clear—once again—that the US government's mass surveillance programs are incompatible with the privacy rights of EU citizens. The judgment was made in the latest case involving Austrian privacy advocate and EFF Pioneer Award winner Max Schrems. It...

item.title: The End of the Arab World's Oil Age Is Nigh
item.description: Pain will be felt across the region

item.title: The Microsoft Police State: Mass Surveillance, Facial Recognition, and the Azure Cloud
item.description: Microsoft helps police surveil and patrol communities through its own offerings and a network of partnerships — while its PR efforts obscure this.

item.title: The Ideological Corruption of Science
item.description: In American laboratories and universities, the spirit of Trofim Lysenko has suddenly been woke.

item.title: Trump Admin Undercuts CDC, Seizes Control of National COVID-19 Data
item.description: New directive is White House's latest attempt to cut the CDC out of the loop.

item.title: Trump Weakens Rules on Environmental Reviews of Infrastructure Projects
item.description: Plan reduces number of projects, such as pipelines and highways, subject to review and limits scope of investigations

item.title: Secret Trump Order Gives CIA More Powers to Launch Cyberattacks
item.description: The Central Intelligence Agency has conducted a series of covert cyber operations against Iran and other targets since winning a secret victory in 2018 when President Trump signed what amounts to a sweeping authorization for such activities, according to former U.S. officials with direct knowledge o…

item.title: Hack of 251 Law Enforcement Websites Exposes Personal Data of 700,000 Cops
item.description: The BlueLeaks archive contains over 16 million rows of data, including emails, descriptions of alleged crimes, and detailed personal information.

item.title: The Dehumanizing Condescension of 'White Fragility'
item.description: The popular book aims to combat racism but talks down to Black people.

item.title: Here's a Map of the Surveillance Tech Police Are Using to Track You

We hear about how law enforcement can match our faces with photos scraped from our social media profiles and monitor us through neighbors' doorbells. The near-w…

item.title: The Defenestration of Bari Weiss
item.description: In London's Hyde Park, the famous Speakers' Corner stands as a tribute to the victory of John Stuart Mill, the most prominent thinker in the liberal tradition. In the occasionally stultifying intellectual climate of Victorian England, Mill led a successful campaign for the right to protest in London…

item.title: Yes, There Is Such a Thing as Cancel Culture
item.description: On July 7th, 153 mostly left-leaning intellectuals wrote a letter to Harper's Magazine, expressing their opposition to 'a new set of moral attitudes and political commitments that tend to weaken our norms of open debate.' The Harper's letter prompted a discussion about the scale, and indeed the exis…

item.title: Your Car Is Spewing Microplastics That Blow Around the World
item.description: When you drive, tiny bits of plastic fly off your tires and brakes. Now scientists have shown how all that road muck is blowing into 'pristine' environments like the Arctic.

item.title: Sound of the Police: How US Law Enforcement Uses Noise as a Weapon
item.description: Potentially harmful military-grade weapons such as flashbangs are being utilized with accelerating regularity at US protests

item.title: Global Methane Emissions Reach a Record High
item.description: Scientists expect emissions, driven by fossil fuels and agriculture, to continue rising rapidly.

item.title: Google Was Just Slapped With a Lawsuit That Claims It Tracks People on Hundreds of Thousands of Apps Even When They Opt Out
item.description: The lawsuit accuses the search engine giant of violating wiretap law and California privacy law by recording what users are looking at in apps.

item.title: Scientists Warn of Rapid Melting of Antarctica's 'Doomsday Glacier'
item.description: Thwaites glacier is losing ice at an accelerating rate, threatening catastrophic sea-level rise

item.title: How Small Satellites Are Radically Remaking Space Exploration
item.description: 'There's so much of the Solar System that we have not explored.'

item.title: When the Left Turns on Its Own
item.description: Bret Weinstein objected to a day without white people at Evergreen State College. Now the professor isn't safe on campus.

item.title: US Citizens Warned They Face Arbitrary Arrest in China
item.description: Amid increased tensions between the two superpowers, the US State Department has issued a formal warning for US citizens in China. It said Americans may face deportation or detention without explanation.

item.title: How to Trick Your Brain to Remember Almost Anything
item.description: Four-time USA Memory Champion Nelson Dellis and psychological scientist Julia Shaw explain how to boost your memory skills.

item.title: Robert Mueller: Roger Stone Remains a Convicted Felon, and Rightly So
item.description: We made every decision in Stone's case, as in all our cases, based solely on the facts and the law and in accordance with the rule of law.

item.title: New Coronavirus Cases in U.S. Soar Past 68,000, Shattering Record
item.description: The number of daily global cases also broke a record, with the United States as the biggest source of new infections. The U.S. death toll is also on the rise.

item.title: 'Witch Hunt': Trump Commutes Longtime Adviser Roger Stone's Prison Sentence
item.description: President Donald Trump commuted the sentence of his longtime friend and adviser Roger Stone, sparing him from prison after he was convicted of lying under oath to lawmakers investigating Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election.

item.title: Why Mexican Cartels Are Shooting Up Drug Rehabs
item.description: Last week's massacre at a drug rehab was the latest in a string of attacks on drug users in Mexico.

item.description: Artificial intelligence firm Dataminr is making questionable use of its Twitter firehose privileges — and not for the first time.

item.description: In Congress, on July 4th, 1776, came the 'unanimous Declaration of the thirteen united States of America.' item.description: And what is wrong with it

item.title: Televangelists, Megachurches Tied to Trump Approved for Millions in Pandemic Aid
item.description: Megachurches and other religious organizations with ties to vocal supporters of U.S. President Donald Trump were approved for millions of dollars in forgivable loans from a taxpayer-funded pandemic aid bailout, according to long-awaited government data released this week.

item.description: On America's birthday, celebrating the corporate-sponsored revolution

item.description: A Harvard graduate who posted a viral video saying she will stab anyone who says 'All Lives Matter' said she has now been fired from her job.

item.description: Crime has been down for decades, but incarceration is still sky-high and brutality cases keep tearing the country apart. Does policing in America need a fundamental re-think?

item.description: A look at the data on aerosol transmission.

item.description: It may be best near-term way to remove CO2, say scientists, but cutting fossil fuel use remains critical

item.description: The report offers a new window into the relationship between tech companies and the U.S. government, as well as an important detail about why such contracts are often difficult to find.

item.title: A Letter on Justice and Open Debate
item.description: The below letter will be appearing in the Letters section of the magazine's October issue. item.title: The Remote British Village That Built One of the Fastest Internet Networks in the UK
item.description: Frustrated by the inability to get good internet, a rural village decided to dig a superfast connection in themselves.

item.description: Maybe you've never noticed, because they don't get a lot of hype but there are hundreds and hundreds of citizen science projects that you can get involved in. These projects range from tagging space observatory photos to transcribing documents that are centuries old. You don't need any special skill…

item.title: Toxic Hand Sanitizers Have Blinded and Killed Adults and Children, FDA Warns
item.description: Blindness, deaths linked to ingestion, but inhalation and absorption also dangerous.

The metaphor goes to the suffocation of hopes, dreams, and basic rights among many black Americans, in…

item.description: Turns out the censorship wasn't a joke by the studio...

item.description: The driver in France was set upon by people who had no tickets and refused to wear face masks.

item.description: Over 350 elephants have died in Botswana since March, sparking a government probe to investigate the mysterious deaths.
